explanation:
- OS_ObjectIdFromToken (implementation): The target function assigns arg.id = OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token). To determine whether this produces or compares null-terminated strings (or internally uses memcmp on strings) the implementation must be inspected.
- OS_Posix_InternalTaskCreate_Impl (implementation): The function calls this routine and passes arg.opaque_arg; memcmp usage could occur in this callee (or in code it calls). The implementation is required to see if memcmp is used on strings there.
- OS_PriorityRemap (implementation): Shown in the call graph as a callee of OS_Posix_InternalTaskCreate_Impl. A memcmp/string-compare violation could be buried one level deeper, so this implementation should be checked.
- OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t (type/union definition): Arg is of this union type and the code comments indicate different union members are used intentionally. We must know the exact types of .id and .opaque_arg (e.g., integer vs pointer to char) to decide whether any memcmp usage would be comparing null-terminated strings.
- OS_object_token_t (type definition): Needed to understand how tokens map to IDs and whether token contents are strings that could lead to memcmp-on-string usage.
- OS_impl_task_internal_record_t (struct definition): The code dereferences impl->id; its type (string vs integer) must be known to determine if any passed/handled values are null-terminated strings that might be compared with memcmp.
- OS_task_internal_record_t (struct definition): Fields task->priority and task->stack_size are used; ensure none are string typed and to fully understand task/impl layout when tracking values to callees.
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (macro definition): This macro is used to obtain task and impl from the token; its expansion determines how the token is used (indexing/lookup) and whether any string handling occurs during that lookup.
- memcmp (standard library function): The MISRA rule concerns memcmp use. The implementation of memcmp (or at least references/usages in the codebase) must be located to see whether it is invoked to compare null-terminated strings within the target function or any of its callees.

Collecting these symbols allows a precise determination of whether the target function (or any callee it invokes) uses memcmp to compare null-terminated strings, which would violate the cited MISRA rule.
